author: djrtwo
content:
sharding relies on being able to *not follow* unavailable chains

note though, that data availability does not guarantee (nor care about) perpetual data persistence. so there is a not a guarantee that data will be available forever but instead taht those that want the data *can* get it when following the tip and then manage it how they please

author: potuz
content: Is that so? I thought the guarantee of sharding is that those that follow the tip *are guaranteed* that the data is available, but there is no enforcement in place to force peers to actually serve it, is there?

author: djrtwo
content: those that want it need to be able to get it. in the worst case, there is *only* sampling. thus data can be retrieved via the sampling mechanism itself (and then reconstructed)

author: djrtwo
content:
sharding assumes DAS works

if DAS works, then the data can be retrieved for recent blocks

author: djrtwo
content: the whole point of DA is to be able to prevent data-withholding attacks which means that the data is in fact availble on the network (in some form) (for some amount of time)

author: potuz
content: Understood, but still it's a way of actually attacking the UX of the network without penalties. Just withhold all data unless asked for DAS. Users would be to be sophisticated enough to restore the data they're interested from the samplings

author: sky.cactus
content: IIUC, data availability sampling enforces (at the protocol layer) that all of the data was sampled (provably) by some portion of attestors.

author: sky.cactus
content: So we can assert that at time of block attestation at least, the data for the block was available and downloaded by `n` validators.

author: sky.cactus
content: Whether those validators are willing to share it is a separate problem, and we want `n` sufficiently high so it is very unlikely that `0 of n` make the data available to the wider network.

author: djrtwo
content: Also nodes sample as well. Not just vals

author: djrtwo
content: And vals will likely be enforced to *custody" a larger amount of data than is required by a node to sample

author: djrtwo
content: Which allows for reconstruction of missing data in emergencies

author: djrtwo
content: Proof of custody (vals) and das (all nodes) complement eachother

author: sky.cactus
content: There is nothing that forces a validator to respond to individual nodes that are sampling though, right?

author: sky.cactus
content: No reward for responding, nor punishment for ignoring.

author: potuz
content: Right, my understanding is that the validator holding the data can and is forced to prove that it has it, but is not required to produce it. At least I have not seen any design that punishes validators that do not serve the actual data
